entry.title: Consuming the Parameterized CDS View using OData in Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

Consuming a parameterized CDS view in SAP Datasphere requires a workaround due to the platform's current limitations. Parameters cannot be directly passed from Datasphere to CDS views.

To address this, we use an OData service and configure a connection with Datasphere to replicate the data.

 

Requirement and Solution Approach

We take the example of the standard CDS View **I_AssetBalanceCube**, which consists of Fiscal Year and Fiscal Period input parameters.

- The requirement is to calculate dynamic values for fiscal year/period based on the system date, pass them to input parameters, and extract the specific period data in Datasphere.

- Another requirement is to extract data for any specific year and period using the TVARV table and passing the values to input parameters in the CDS view.

 

Steps

  • Created an ABAP class **ZCLFI_ASSET_BALANCE_DATA** with method **GET_ASSET_BALANCE** to fetch the asset balance records. This class is passed to the OData section, which passes logic to the input parameter of **I_AssetBalanceCube**.       

     

     

  METHOD get_asset_balance.

    DATA : lv_fiscalyear TYPE fis_gjahr,
           lv_fisperiod  TYPE fis_poper.

    DATA : v_year  TYPE fis_gjahr,
           v_month TYPE n LENGTH 2,
           v_day   TYPE n LENGTH 2,
           v_high  TYPE sydate,
           v_low   TYPE sydate.


    CONSTANTS : lc_keyfig                TYPE c LENGTH 10 VALUE 'AHS',
                lc_keyfig_plan           TYPE c LENGTH 10 VALUE 'AHS_PLAN',
                lc_fiscal_asst_balanc    TYPE c LENGTH 30 VALUE 'ZFI_DS_ABFISCALYEAR',
                lc_fisperiod_asst_balanc TYPE c LENGTH 30 VALUE 'ZFI_DS_FISCALPERIOD',
                lc_type                  TYPE c VALUE 'P'.

*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Get the fixed values from TVARVC
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Get TVARV variable GJAHR - Fiscal Year
    zclca_utility_cloud=>get_tvarv( EXPORTING iv_name = lc_fiscal_asst_balanc iv_type = lc_type IMPORTING et_tvarv = DATA(lt_fiscal) ).

* Extract the year and the month from Sysdate
    v_month = sy-datum+4(2).

    lv_fiscalyear = VALUE #( lt_fiscal[ 1 ]-low OPTIONAL ).

    IF lv_fiscalyear IS INITIAL.

      CASE v_month.
        WHEN '10'.
          lv_fiscalyear =  sy-datum(4) + 1.
        WHEN '11'.
          lv_fiscalyear =  sy-datum(4) + 1.
        WHEN '12'.
          lv_fiscalyear =  sy-datum(4) + 1.
        WHEN OTHERS.
          lv_fiscalyear =  sy-datum(4).

      ENDCASE.
*      lv_fiscalyear =  sy-datum(4) - 1.
      v_low = |{ sy-datum(4) - 1 }| & |10| & |01|.   "For Asset Capitalization Date
    ELSE.
* If TVARV variable GJAHR - Fiscal Year is available then calculate Low value Capitalization Date
      v_low = |{ lv_fiscalyear - 1 }| & |10| & |01|.   "For Asset Capitalization Date

    ENDIF.

* Get TVARV variable POPER - Fiscal Period
    zclca_utility_cloud=>get_tvarv( EXPORTING iv_name = lc_fisperiod_asst_balanc iv_type = lc_type IMPORTING et_tvarv = DATA(lt_fisperiod) ).

    lv_fisperiod = VALUE #( lt_fisperiod[ 1 ]-low OPTIONAL ).
    IF lv_fisperiod IS INITIAL.
*      lv_fisperiod = sy-datum+4(2).
      CASE v_month.
        WHEN '10'.
          lv_fisperiod =  '001'.
        WHEN '11'.
          lv_fisperiod =  '002'.
        WHEN '12'.
          lv_fisperiod =  '003'.

      ENDCASE.

    ENDIF.

* Fetch the data based on TVARV table
* business required AssetAccountingKeyFigureSet 'AHS' and 'AHS_PLAN' data in single parameter
* So segregate the two select statement and combine both data in one final internal table it_asst_balance_data

    SELECT
      FROM I_AssetBalanceCube( P_AssetAccountingKeyFigureSet = _keyfig,
                                 P_FiscalYear = _fiscalyear,
                                 P_FiscalPeriod = _fisperiod,
                                 P_KeyDate =  )  WITH
      PRIVILEGED ACCESS
*                                      INTO TABLE (lt_data).
      FIELDS *
      WHERE AssetCapitalizationDate >= @v_low AND AssetCapitalizationDate <= 
      INTO TABLE (lt_data).
*this is AssetAccountingKeyFigureSet 'AHS_PLAN'
    SELECT
    FROM I_AssetBalanceCube( P_AssetAccountingKeyFigureSet = _keyfig_plan,
                               P_FiscalYear = _fiscalyear,
                               P_FiscalPeriod = _fisperiod,
                               P_KeyDate =  )  WITH
    PRIVILEGED ACCESS
    FIELDS *
    WHERE AssetCapitalizationDate >= @v_low AND AssetCapitalizationDate <= 
    APPENDING TABLE _data.


    LOOP AT lt_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_data>).
      APPEND INITIAL LINE TO it_asst_balance_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_asset>).

      <lfs_asset> = CORRESPONDING #( <lfs_data> ).

    ENDLOOP.


  ENDMETHOD.
  • Created an OData Project **ZFI_FOR_ASSET_BALANCE** and structure. **ZFIS_ASSET_BALANCE_ODATA**.

     

     

  • Generated OData service **ZFI_FOR_ASSET_BALANCE_SRV.                                                                      

     

  • Created the **DPC_EXT Class - ZCL_ZFI_FOR_ASSET_BALA_DPC_EXT** and redefined the method **ASSET_BALANCESET_GET_ENTITYSET**. This method calls the data provider class `zclfi_asset_balance_data=>get_asset_balance` and passes it to the OData exporting entity set.
     
     

     

  • Generated OData URL for connection-https://vhcuhs4xcs.sap.***.com.au:44300/sap/opu/odata/sap/ZFI_FOR_ASSET_BALANCE_SRV`

 

  • Created and configured the OData connection in Datasphere and validated it. 

 

  •  In the Data Builder, created a Dataflow to replicate data from the OData connection. 

 

  • The flow was then executed. Data was loaded into a Datasphere local table based on the input parameter logic written in the ABAP class method. 

 

 

Output

The data is successfully replicated in the local Datasphere table.
You can also replicate data from the local table to a non-SAP target (such as ADLS) by creating a replication flow and using the local table as the source. 

 

Conclusion

Using OData as a workaround enables the consumption of parameterized CDS views in SAP Datasphere. This approach ensures flexibility in handling dynamic and specific parameter values, allowing seamless integration with SAP and non-SAP targets.

entry.title: Streamlining REST API Integrations in SAP Datasphere with Task Chains and FastAPI on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction 

With the recent introduction of API Tasks in Task Chains, SAP Datasphere now supports direct orchestration of external REST services (see SAP documentation). This enhancement unlocks new integration possibilities, particularly for scenarios where no standard connectors are available. 

In our use case, we aim to extract data from an open REST API and load it into SAP Datasphere. To achieve this, we developed a custom wrapper API‚Äîbuilt with FastAPI and hosted on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)‚Äîthat handles both data extraction and the writing of that data into SAP HANA Cloud, which underlies SAP Datasphere. The entire data loading process is then triggered and managed via a REST API step within a Task Chain. 

At the core of this solution is a lightweight microservice that seamlessly integrates a third-party REST API into SAP Datasphere. The microservice is designed to be modular, secure, and easy to maintain, and enables a fully automated integration pipeline. 

Key Features of the Approach 

  • REST API extraction wrapped in a FastAPI-based microservice 
  • Basic HTTP Authentication for secure access 
  • Data retrieval from public or external REST APIs 
  • Automatic detection and mapping of SAP HANA-compatible data types 
  • Dynamic table creation in SAP HANA Cloud 
  • Batch data insertion with upload timestamps for traceability 
  • Deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) 
  • Registration as an HTTP connection in SAP Datasphere 
  • Integration into a Task Chain for full orchestration of the data workflow 

 

 

Requirement 

Data integration from 3rd-party REST APIs is still a challenge in SAP Datasphere, particularly when no standard connectors are available. SAP offers solutions like Open Connectors or SAP Cloud Integration via the Integration Suite. However, these options come with additional cost and infrastructure overhead. 

Our proposed solution is a lightweight, developer-friendly alternative that utilizes: 

  • A simple REST service hosted on SAP BTP 
  • Open SQL schema access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud instance 
  • Integration into Task Chains via the new REST API task type 

This allows full orchestration and governance from within SAP Datasphere, without introducing unnecessary middleware layers. 

Solution 

FastAPI Solution on SAP BTP 

At the core of this architecture lies a microservice built with FastAPI. This Python-based service acts as a universal adapter to extract, transform (lightly), and load data into SAP HANA Cloud. The code can also be found in our GIT repository. 

Key Components 

  1. Authentication 
    All secure endpoints require HTTP Basic Authentication, with credentials configurable via environment variables. 
  2. HANA Integration 
    1. Using the hana_ml library, the service connects to the HANA Cloud database and  
      automatically detects column types using heuristics (e.g., timestamp recognition, length-adjusted NVARCHAR) 
    2. Dynamically creates a table if it doesn't exist 
    3. Inserts records in batch mode, with an added UPLOAD_TS timestamp column 

  3. Endpoints

    Endpoint 

    Method 

    Description 

    / 

    GET 

    Health check 

    /test-hana-connection 

    GET 

    Verifies database credentials and connection 

    /extract-and-write 

    POST 

    Triggers extraction from a third-party API and writes to HANA 

    /preview-data 

    GET 

    Fetches sample records from a REST API 

    /infer-types 

    GET 

    Infers HANA-compatible types from JSON response 

  4. Deployment 
    The service is packaged with a manifest.yaml for deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry). It uses the Python buildpack and runs via uvicorn in production. 
     

Outlook 

This FastAPI-based solution can be flexibly extended to support more advanced integration needs: 

  • Authentication: Easily add OAuth2, API keys, or Bearer tokens to handle secured APIs. 
  • REST Call Chaining: Implement multi-step workflows by chaining dependent API calls asynchronously. 
  • Pagination: Add logic for offset, cursor, or token-based pagination to collect full datasets. 
  • Schema Flexibility: Support field renaming, normalization of nested JSON, and custom type overrides. 

Testing 

For Testing purposes we tested everything with Postman and the public available Harry Potter API https://hp-api.onrender.com. 

SAP Datasphere Integration 

To communicate with this BTP service we performed the following steps: 

  1. Whitelist the IPs of our BTP instance in the SAP Datasphere tenant (For testing from Business Application Studio (BAS)you may also want to whitelist those IPs as well) 
  2. Create a HTTP connection for the usage in the Task Chain 

     

     

In the task chain we can now add this step and configure the body. 

 

 

In the Configuration panel we can now select our HTTP connection: 

 

 

And also configure our REST call: 

After running the Task Chain we can see the data is now loaded into our table. 

 

Conclusion 

The integration of a FastAPI-based microservice into SAP Datasphere via Task Chains marks a significant advancement in streamlining data ingestion from third-party REST APIs. By leveraging SAP BTP for deployment and utilizing the new REST API task type within Task Chains, we demonstrated a lightweight and developer-friendly alternative to traditional integration tools like SAP Cloud Integration or Open Connectors. 

Looking ahead, the framework can be extended to accommodate more complex data workflows, robust security models, and advanced transformation logic. With this foundation, organizations can seamlessly orchestrate external data services within SAP Datasphere while maintaining full control, traceability, and governance‚Äîall without the need for additional middleware. 

Links: 

For Integration possibilities with Open Connectors and Fast API deployment you can also take a look at my other blogs 

ZPARTNER Links: 

  • https://www.zpartner.eu/automating-sap-datasphere-task-chains-with-cli-wrapping-fastapi-integration-with-sap-analytics-cloud/ 
  • https://www.zpartner.eu/mastering-custom-integrations-in-sap-datasphere-leveraging-open-connectors-for-rest-apis/ 

SAP Community Links: 

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/automating-sap-dsp-task-chains-with-cli-wrapping-fastapi-integration-with/ba-p/13874275 
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/mastering-custom-integrations-in-sap-datasphere-leveraging-open-connectors/ba-p/13990658

entry.title: SAP Activate Methodology for SAP Business Data Cloud - New Roadmap Release in SAP Roadmap Viewer
entry.content:
Have you wondered how to implement SAP Business Data Cloud? If so, great news can be found in this blog!

SAP has announced SAP Business Data Cloud as part of the event "SAP Business Unleashed" in February this year. 

‚ÄúSAP Business Data Cloud unleashes the full value of enterprise data for Business AI,‚Äù said SAP CEO Christian Klein. ‚ÄúEvery company on the planet wants to get more value out of their data and greater returns on their AI investments,‚Äù said Ali Ghodsi, Co-founder and CEO of Databricks. ‚ÄúBy joining forces with SAP, we‚Äôre helping organizations bring together all their data ‚Äî regardless of format or where it lives". 

SAP Business Data Cloud was released with controlled availability on February 13, 2025 and is has now been generally available since April. A great FAQ blog was created in March: SAP Business Data Cloud FAQ. 

We are now excited to announce that the implementation roadmap for SAP Business Data Cloud is now available in SAP Roadmap Viewer: SAP Activate Methodology for SAP Business Data Cloud.

Its content covers all SAP Activate phases of an SAP Business Data Cloud implementation project from DISCOVER to RUN:

  • Licensing model and licensing SAP Business Data Cloud.
  • How to request free discovery workshops and assessments for SAP Business Data Cloud.
  • The provisioning process for SAP Business Data Cloud and its core components.
  • Access to learning and onboarding sources.
  • How to connect the solution to its core components and data sources .
  • General project management tasks like Organizational Change Management, End-User enablement and execution and monitoring of an SAP implementation project.

What are SAP Activate Roadmaps in general? They provide:

  • A clear sequence of tasks to follow to implement a specific SAP solution
  • Helpful guidance and best practices for system provisioning
  • Links to key accelerators, tools, and resources
  • A smooth handover from request to configuration and readiness for project work.

Have a look at the existing SAP Activate roadmaps in SAP Roadmap Viewer: https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer:

How to provide feedback: 

  1. You can provide feedback directly in road map viewer while viewing the content. Refer to blog Providing Feedback in SAP Activate road map viewer.
  2. Send us a direct email via: sapactivate@sap.com.
  3. Leave us your comments in the section below.

Thank you for reading!

Ariane

entry.title: SAP Datasphere - How to configure the AWS Assume Role option for an AWS S3 connection
entry.content:
I have been seeing questions on the S3 connection option to Assume Role in SAP Datasphere.  This article shows how I set up my S3 connection in SAP Datasphere to use this functionality. 

There are multiple methods to connect to AWS S3, this is one approach that may work for your environment.   SAP Datasphere can be deployed on multiple hyperscalers so this approach works for all deployments of SAP Datasphere.   The details for the S3 connection in SAP Datasphere are available in our help documentation. 

Disclaimer - I am not a deep AWS expert, please verify any security deployments with your AWS team.

 

I started with this AWS Reference link: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/code-library/latest/ug/iam_example_iam_Scenario_CreateUserAssumeRole_section.html

Summary: 

  • Create a S3 user with no permissions and secret key/access key
  • Create a role that grants permission to list Amazon S3 buckets for the account.
  • Add a policy to let the user assume the role
  • Assume the role and list S3 buckets using temporary credentials, then clean up resources.

FIrst we create a user with no permissions in AWS

Then create Access Keys for the user:

Note the keys down for use in the SAP Datasphere connection.  

Next, create a role that allows the sts:AssumeRole permission.  Capture the ARN for this role to be used in the SAP Datasphere connection. 

Here's the role I created, with my account ID removed:

Role
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {
                "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::<REPLACE with your AWS Acct ID>:user/assume_user_demo_no_permissions"
            },
            "Action": "sts:AssumeRole"
        }
    ]
}

 

Now create a Policy that exposes the AWS S3 bucket(s):

Here's the Policy definition I used - please adjust it if necessary based on your specific requirements:

 

Policy: 
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Sid": "VisualEditor0",
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": [
                "s3:ListTagsForResource",
                "s3:PutObject",
                "s3:GetObject",
                "s3:ListBucketMultipartUploads",
                "s3:PutObjectRetention",
                "s3:DeleteObjectVersion",
                "s3:GetObjectTagging",
                "s3:ListBucket",
                "s3:DeleteObject",
                "s3:GetBucketAcl",
                "s3:GetBucketPolicy"
            ],
            "Resource": [
                "arn:aws:s3:*:REPLACE with your AWS Acct ID>:access-grants/default/grant/*",
                "arn:aws:s3:::assume-role-bucket-dsp",
                "arn:aws:s3:::*/*",
                "arn:aws:s3:*:REPLACE with your AWS Acct ID>:storage-lens-group/*",
                "arn:aws:s3:*:REPLACE with your AWS Acct ID>:access-grants/default/location/*",
                "arn:aws:s3:*:REPLACE with your AWS Acct ID>:access-grants/default"
            ]
        },
        {
            "Sid": "VisualEditor1",
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "s3:ListAllMyBuckets",
            "Resource": "*"
        }
    ]
}

Create the S3 Bucket Policy

 

Bucket Policy:

Bucket policy: 
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Deny",
            "Principal": "*",
            "Action": "s3:*",
            "Resource": [
                "arn:aws:s3:::assume-role-bucket-dsp",
                "arn:aws:s3:::assume-role-bucket-dsp/*"
            ],
            "Condition": {
                "Bool": {
                    "aws:SecureTransport": "false"
                },
                "NumericLessThan": {
                    "s3:TlsVersion": "1.2"
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}

 

Now that you have the secret key/access key and ARN for the assume role, you can create the connection in SAP Datasphere..  Navigate to your Connections area within your Space and select Amazon Simple Storage Service:

Note the endpoint contains the region in format:   s3.<region>.amazonaws.com.   Enable Assume Role by changing the value of Use Assume Role to true and Include the Role ARN in the Assume Role section of the Connection. 

Save and Validate the connection in SAP Datasphere

If you used my Role and Policy, then using S3 as a target in Replication Flows will work!

entry.title: Lead in the Age of AI, Start with Your Data
entry.content:
At a Glance: Lead in the Age of AI, Start with Your Data  

AI is only as powerful as the data it runs on. Inaccurate context, broken semantics, or outdated master data can turn automation from an advantage into a risk‚Äîcosting companies millions each year in delays, errors, and lost trust.  

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a trusted data foundation by preserving semantics, logic, and context of enterprise data. This eliminates manual data work, accelerates decision-making, and enables CFOs, COOs, and CIOs to act on accurate, contextual data.

Leading companies are already replacing manual workarounds with reusable data products, harmonized KPIs, and automated reconciliations.  SAP Business Data Cloud is launching a hands-on webinar series to help organizations unleash speed, trust, and impact with their data.

Learn more:Getting Started Series: Experience SAP Business Data Cloud

Full article: Lead in the Age of AI, Start with Your Data

Imagine an AI that automatically optimizes pricing to clear inventory while protecting margins‚Äîwithout human input. Now imagine that AI running on inaccurate data: the wrong currency, outdated master data, or misaligned cost centers. Suddenly, automation isn‚Äôt an advantage‚Äîit‚Äôs a risk. 

This is why data can no longer be treated as a back-office IT asset‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic business capability. The companies leading in AI aren‚Äôt the ones with the most data, but the ones with the right data, at the right time, with the right context. 

When Poor Data Foundations Impact the Bottom Line  

According to Forrester, poor data quality costs organizations over $5 million annually. Even more alarming, 7% report losses of $25 million or more (Forrester, 2024). Gartner research reinforces this reality.  In a 2020 study, Gartner found that poor data quality costs organizations an average of $12.9 million annually (Gartner 2020).  

It‚Äôs rarely the volume of data that slows organizations down‚Äîit‚Äôs the lack of business context. Poorly managed master data, disconnected hierarchies, missing lineage, and duplicated logic all contribute to fragmented views that undermine trust, delay decisions, and increase cost. 

The typical workaround? Manual fixes: recreating data context, writing custom scripts, and rebuilding SAP‚Äôs logic in other tools. These solutions are often fragile, expensive, manual and error prone. When systems change or org structures realign, the fixes can break‚Äîand IT has a new project all over again. 

The result: every decision takes longer, and every delay carries a cost. 

The consequences are real: 

  • Product profitability becomes unreliable if cost and pricing data use different hierarchies 
  • Regional forecasting fails when customer hierarchies are inconsistent 
  • KPIs vary between teams because each is working with different assumptions 

The impact on business leaders: 

  • CFOs risk inaccurate forecasts, delayed closes, and loss in profits 
  • COOs waste time waiting on reconciling reports instead of driving execution 
  • CIOs / CDOs see mounting costs as teams duplicate work, rebuild logic, and rely on shadow systems 

Leading companies are changing course‚Äînot by rebuilding data outside SAP, but by activating the trusted business logic already in place. 

Unleash Speed, Trust, and Impact with SAP Business Data Cloud  

SAP Business Data Cloud helps organizations turn fragmented data into a trusted foundation for decision-making. By unifying data across systems and preserving the business context that gives it meaning it significantly reduces the need for manual reconciliation or reengineering.  

The result is now reversed because the data is accurate, and actionable, enabling faster execution, stronger alignment, and higher return on data investments. 

How SAP Business Data Cloud strengthens enterprise data foundations: 

  • Preserve context natively: context, semantics, logic, and hierarchies stay intact‚Äîno rework needed. 
  • Deliver trusted, reusable data products: Instead of manually preparing data for every model or report, teams can access governed, curated assets that reflect real business truth. 
  • Empower intelligent applications: With high-quality, harmonized data at their core, applications for planning, forecasting, sustainability, and operations drive insights where decisions happen real time‚Äînot after the fact. 

Customer Transformation in Action 
Discover how leading organizations are transforming their business with trusted data. Here‚Äôs a collection of customer testimonials showcasing how SAP helps companies tackle opportunities across industries‚Äîwhether through modernization, real-time decision-making, or unlocking new growth powered by SAP Business Data Cloud. 

SAP Featured Stories for Business Data Cloud 

Experience SAP Business Data Cloud First-Hand:
To experience the power of SAP Business Data Cloud, join a hands-on webinar series designed to accelerate data strategies. Across a series of interactive modules, here SAP‚Äôs product and leadership teams guide participants through practical steps to unlock business value from their data.  

Topics include:  

  • Build and simulate outcomes with Intelligent Applications 
  • Accelerate AI innovation with SAP Databricks 
  • Create analytical models and data products in SAP Datasphere

Learn directly from some of the industry experts on how to turn data into a true business driver.

Learn more: Getting Started Series: Experience SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: DSP SQL Navigator ‚Äì Stop copy pasting URLs!
entry.content:
I have been working with SAP Datasphere since 2019, back when it was still called SAP Data Warehouse Cloud (DWC). Obviously I have built my fair share of SQL views, and have been analyzing SQL views even more. That means a lot of jumping from one SQL view to another, which I do through copy-pasting the URL that I am currently on and changing it to the view I want to jump to. I must have copy-pasted hours on end since 2019 on a daily basis. But that is now behind me, and I will make sure you don‚Äôt have to anymore as well!

So like I wrote in the introduction, what I do to jump from one SQL view, to the view that lies beneath it is:

  • Copy the current URL
  • Copy the view name I want to jump into
  • Overwrite the last part of the URL with this view name.

I have always thought there must be a faster way to do this. With the upcoming of ‚Äúvibe-coding‚Äù and tools like Cursor and Claude Code, I finally tried to make my day a lot easier, by trying to code a browser extension.

Together with Claude I wrote a Product Requirement Document (PRD) and started working on the project together with Claude Code. Within a few hours the first useful version of the browser extension could be imported into my browser, and just a few hours later I had a polished version that I am now ready to share with you!

The plugin basically automated my old workflow. When you are in a SQL view and want to jump to the SQL view underneath that one, you simply select the view you want to jump to and press your hotkey and it open a new browser tab and open up that view for you!

Want to try it out? Basically all you have to do is download the plugin browser from the Google Web Store through this link. Then you have to assign a hotkey via the settings of the plugin and it works! You can also first check the demo if you want in this Youtube movie, where I show off the process! 

I am currently still working on the feature to jump to a view that is shared from another space, and will bring a new version of the plugin as soon as possible. If you have any questions please feel free to reach out to me!

entry.title: End-to-End Business Transformation with SAP AI Tools: A Practical Example
entry.content:
Introduction: Simplifying Grocery Business with AI ü•¶üõí

Grocery businesses handling food items and eatables want to deliver products faster, reduce mistakes, and delight customers. SAP offers a suite of AI tools that can automate, predict, and optimize business processes. In this example, we‚Äôll show how a large grocery chain can transform its Order-to-Cash (O2C) process‚Äîfrom receiving orders to delivering products and receiving payments‚Äîusing SAP AI tools.

Note: O2C is the flow where a customer places an order, the company delivers the product, and receives payment.

1. Organizing Data with SAP Datasphere üè¢üíæüìä

Objective: Combine data from sales, inventory, shipments, and suppliers into one view.

How it works:

  • Connect SAP systems and external sources (like supply chain partners and e-commerce platforms) üîó.

  • Transform raw data into business-friendly models for orders, deliveries, and payments üóÇÔ∏è.

Benefit for growth:
A grocery chain can reduce stock-outs and overstock üìâ, understand customer buying patterns üõçÔ∏è, and ensure timely deliveries üöö. With a single source of truth, managers make faster and more informed decisions üß†.

Analogy: Central nervous system ‚Äì integrates and harmonizes all data from multiple sources.

2. Managing AI Services with SAP AI Foundation ‚öôÔ∏èüõ†Ô∏èüìà

Objective: Provide infrastructure and services to deploy, monitor, and orchestrate AI models efficiently.

How it works:

  • SAP AI Foundation handles model orchestration, monitoring, logging, and deployment pipelines üñ•Ô∏è.

  • Works seamlessly with AI Core, ML DI tenants, and other AI services üîÑ.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can scale AI solutions reliably ‚ö°, ensuring smooth operations across multiple stores and warehouses üè¨ without disruptions. Managers can monitor model performance in real-time üïµÔ∏è, improving efficiency and reducing costs üí∞.

Analogy: AI control center ‚Äì orchestrates and monitors AI models and workflows.

3. Predicting Outcomes with SAP AI Core & ML DI Tenants ü§ñüì°üîÆ

Objective: Predict delivery delays, demand spikes, or payment issues.

How it works:

  • Build predictive models in SAP AI Core üß©.

  • Use ML DI tenants to access pre-trained AI models or train new ones using integrated data from SAP Datasphere üóÑÔ∏è.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can anticipate high-demand periods üìà, avoid perishable food wastage ü•¨‚ùå, and ensure timely replenishment üöõ. Predictive insights also help in identifying potential payment delays üí≥ or customer churn üîÑ, boosting revenue and trust.

Analogy: Predictive brain ‚Äì builds and deploys AI models for forecasting and insights.

4. Automating Tasks with SAP Build Process Automation üîÑü§ñüìù

Objective: Reduce manual work and speed up processes.

How it works:

  • Automate routine O2C tasks like approving orders ‚úÖ, sending invoices üßæ, and following up on payments üì¨.

  • Integrate AI predictions to trigger actions automatically ‚ö°.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can process orders faster ‚è±Ô∏è, minimize human errors ‚ùå, and focus staff on higher-value tasks üíº. Automation ensures smoother operations and higher customer satisfaction üòÉ.

Analogy: Workflow robot ‚Äì automates repetitive tasks and business processes.

5. Guiding Employees with SAP Joule üí°üìåüßë‚Äçüíº

Objective: Provide real-time insights and recommendations.

How it works:

  • SAP Joule offers suggestions, such as which deliveries might be delayed ‚è≥ or which customers need follow-up üìû.

  • Employees can take immediate, informed actions üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è.

Benefit for growth:
Employees make smarter decisions faster ‚ö°, improving delivery efficiency üöö, customer loyalty ‚ù§Ô∏è, and operational agility üè¨. Real-time guidance reduces mistakes and accelerates response times ‚è±Ô∏è.

Analogy: Smart advisor ‚Äì gives insights in real-time.

6. Integrating Security & Identity with SAP BTP IAS/IPS üîíüõ°Ô∏èüîë

Objective: Secure AI and process automation tools while ensuring correct user access.

How it works:

  • IAS manages Single Sign-On (SSO) üîê for employees interacting with SAP AI tools.

  • IPS ensures only authorized users are provisioned into the system üë§.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain protects sensitive customer and supplier data üóÇÔ∏è, ensures compliance üìã, and safely enables access to AI tools across multiple locations üåê.

Analogy: Security gatekeeper ‚Äì ensures authorized access to AI tools & data.

7. Monitoring & Continuous Improvement with SAP Cloud ALM üìäüñ•Ô∏è‚ö°

Objective: Ensure the system works well and keeps improving.

How it works:

  • Track AI model performance and automated workflows using SAP Cloud ALM üìà.

  • Use feedback and metrics to refine AI models and automations üîÑ.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can continuously improve operations üè¨, adapt to market changes üîÑ, and maintain high customer satisfaction üòÉ. Monitoring helps spot inefficiencies before they affect operations ‚ö†Ô∏è.

Analogy: System monitor ‚Äì tracks performance & supports continuous improvement.

8. Enabling Real-Time Events with SAP Event Mesh üåê‚ö°

Objective: Ensure real-time communication between systems and trigger actions instantly across the O2C process.

How it works:

  • SAP Event Mesh enables event-driven messaging, connecting orders, inventory updates, delivery notifications, and payment confirmations.

  • Works seamlessly with SAP Build Process Automation and AI predictions to trigger automated workflows immediately.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can respond instantly to order changes, prevent stockouts, and ensure customers get accurate delivery updates üööüì≤. Real-time events also help coordinate multiple stores and warehouses efficiently üè¨, improving overall operational agility.

Analogy: Real-time traffic controller ‚Äì directs information instantly to where it‚Äôs needed, keeping the flow smooth.

9. Business Insights with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) üìäüí°

Objective: Turn all collected data and AI predictions into actionable dashboards and reports.

How it works:

  • SAC connects to SAP Datasphere and AI Core models to provide interactive dashboards, forecasts, and KPI tracking.

  • Managers and executives can visualize order trends, inventory levels, and delivery performance in real-time.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can make data-driven strategic decisions, optimize promotions, plan inventory better, and track overall performance üìà. This strengthens customer satisfaction and profitability.

Analogy: Digital dashboard ‚Äì shows the full picture at a glance for informed decisions.

Industry Example / Use Case Snapshot ü•¨üì¶

Scenario: A grocery chain receives an online order for fresh produce, including perishable vegetables and fruits.

End-to-End Flow Using SAP Tools:

  1. Data Integration (SAP Datasphere üè¢üíæ)

    • The order details, inventory levels, and supplier availability are immediately centralized.

  2. Predictive Insights (SAP AI Core & ML DI ü§ñ)

    • AI predicts potential delivery delays due to traffic or stock shortages and estimates optimal delivery routes.

  3. Automation (SAP Build Process Automation üîÑü§ñ)

    • The system automatically confirms the order, checks stock, and triggers procurement if needed.

  4. Real-Time Events (SAP Event Mesh üåê‚ö°)

    • Updates on stock, delivery status, and payment confirmations are shared instantly across all systems.

  5. Employee Guidance (SAP Joule üí°üßë‚Äçüíº)

    • Warehouse staff receive recommendations on packing priorities for perishable items to minimize spoilage.

  6. Analytics & Reporting (SAC üìäüí°)

    • Managers monitor order fulfillment KPIs, customer satisfaction, and stock movement in dashboards.

  7. Monitoring & Continuous Improvement (Cloud ALM üìä‚ö°)

    • Performance metrics from this order feed into ongoing AI model tuning and process optimization.

Outcome:

  • The perishable order is delivered fresh, on time, and with minimal wastage.

  • Employees work efficiently guided by AI insights.

  • Managers gain actionable insights, helping the grocery chain increase customer satisfaction and reduce losses.

Key Takeaways ‚úÖ

  • Streamlined Operations üè¢ü§ñ: SAP tools optimize the entire Order-to-Cash workflow.

  • Smart Decisions üí°üìä: AI predictions and dashboards support faster, data-driven choices.

  • Automation & Real-Time ‚ö°üîÑ: Workflows run instantly with minimal manual effort.

  • Guided Workforce üßë‚Äçüíºüí°: Employees get actionable insights in real time.

  • Secure & Monitored üîíüìä: Access is controlled and performance continuously tracked.

  • Customer Satisfaction üöö‚ù§Ô∏è: Faster fulfillment, fewer errors, and smarter operations boost growth.

Ask & Learn ü§î

Q1: What is Order-to-Cash (O2C)?
It‚Äôs the process of taking a customer order, delivering the product, and receiving payment.

Q2: Do I need technical skills to use these SAP AI tools?
No. Tools like SAP Joule and SAC provide simple insights and dashboards that non-technical employees can use.

Q3: How does SAP Event Mesh help in this workflow?
Event Mesh enables real-time messaging between systems, triggering automated workflows instantly for faster operations.

Q4: Can automation replace employees?
Automation handles repetitive tasks, allowing employees to focus on higher-value work and make smarter decisions with AI guidance.

Q5: How does SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) add value?
SAC converts data and AI predictions into dashboards and KPIs, enabling strategic and operational decisions.

Q6: How is data security ensured?
SAP BTP IAS/IPS manages user authentication and provisioning, ensuring only authorized access to AI tools and sensitive data.

Q7: How do I measure improvement?
SAP Cloud ALM tracks system performance, AI model effectiveness, and workflow efficiency for continuous improvement.

entry.title: Release Navigator for SAP BTP - What's New in Q3 2025
entry.content:
The Release Navigator for SAP BTP continues to evolve and expand, offering our customers improved resources and streamlined access to product updates.

With the Q3 2025 update, we ensured all content is up-to-date and we are excited to announce the addition of a new product page for SAP Customer Data Solutions as well as some cosmetic UI updates. Read more about the details in this blog post.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Collaborating closely with SAP BTP experts, we've expanded the release coverage by introducing 11 new product pages. These pages compile links to all available release information, such as schedules, pre- and post-release communications, blogs, and more:

  • SAP Customer Data Solutions, including
    • SAP Customer Data Cloud / SAP Customer Identity and Access Management
    • SAP Customer Data Platform

Read on to see what you can find on this new page.

SAP Customer Data Solutions

This page contains specific resources for SAP Customer Identity and Access Management, SAP Customer Data Platform, as well as release resources relevant across different SAP Customer Data Solutions. Here‚Äôs a list of all you can find on this page:

  • SAP Customer Identity and Access Management (CDC)
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • What‚Äôs New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • SAP Customer Data Platform
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • What‚Äôs New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • General Customer Data Solutions Resources
    • SAP BTP Newsletter
    • Enablement Webcasts
    • Subscription link to Cloud Availability Center

Please Note: This page has previously been available via the Release Navigator for Customer Experience. Adding this page to the Release Navigator for SAP BTP reflects the move of SAP Customer Data Solutions from the Customer Experience area to SAP BTP. The page in the Release Navigator for Customer Experience will stay online until the beginning of Q4 2025 for everyone to take note and switch out their potential bookmarks or saved links. After that, only the page within the Release Navigator for SAP BTP will remain available.

Check it out.

 

 

With this last round of updates, we added new visual elements to all release navigators. The UI updates in the Release Navigator for SAP BTP do not affect functionality or performance and are strictly cosmetical.

On the home page also known as the Product Specific page, you will notice that our Welcome and Release Calendar cards have received a facelift for a fresher look and feel. 

On all pages where you can open informational text boxes by hovering over the lightbulb icon, you will see a slight update to the design of these boxes. Content and functionality remain the same. 

As a reminder: These pop-up boxes show up on every page with a lightbulb icon at the top and may be moved around on the page or closed once you are done reading them.

 

 

For centralized information regarding the release of new features for SAP BTP products and services, consult the Consolidated Release Schedule for SAP BTP.

Regarding the Release Navigator updates, refer to this update plan:

*Disclaimer: The schedule is subject to alterations without notice, including potential delays or the integration of changes in subsequent update windows. It doesn't establish a commitment, promise, or legal duty to deliver any material, code, or functionality. Looking into the remaining quarters of 2025, updates will focus on quarterly content maintenance and a steady extension of product coverage. No substantial UI updates are planned for the time being.

 

 

The Readiness@Scale team within SAP Enterprise Support is driven to ensure release readiness across the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio. Our mission is to empower SAP customers to effectively adopt and utilize innovations.

If you have feedback or specific requests for content within the release navigator, feel free to contact us.

Don't forget to explore our team‚Äôs blogs tagged under Readiness@Scale.

Happy navigating!

Readiness@Scale  
SAP Enterprise Support
